Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Spatial and Temporal Variability in CDOM by Optical Remote Sensing: Effects on Water Quality, Water Treatment, and Aquatic Ecosystem Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1510332
Hozalski

Dissolved organic matter occurs in all natural waters, and chromophoric dissolved organic matter is the most abundant fraction in many natural waters, especially in forested watersheds with wetlands. Dissolved organic matter and chromophoric dissolved organic matter strongly affects water quality through its ability to mobilize metals and hydrophobic chemicals, serve as a source of reactive photochemical intermediates, and control many aquatic ecosystem processes. Dissolved organic matter has negative effects on production of safe drinking water resulting from the formation is disinfection by-products in treatment plants. This project will dramatically improve the state of knowledge on chromophoric dissolved organic matter by refining procedures to retrieve chromophoric dissolved organic matter from satellite imagery, using the new (Landsat 8) and forthcoming satellites.

This project will enable the first census-level assessment of chromophoric dissolved organic matter levels across a large region comprising three major ecoregions of the Upper Midwest. The goals of this multidisciplinary project are to leverage the teams optical remote sensing capabilities with modern field and lab techniques to: (i) dramatically improve understanding of the distribution, time trends, and environmental factors affecting Dissolved organic matter and chromophoric dissolved organic matter levels in surface waters and (ii) advance understanding of their source-dependent characteristics relevant to their potential to cause water treatment problems. With specific objectives of the proposed to: (1) develop robust equations to retrieve chromophoric dissolved organic matter data from satellite imagery and use the results to develop census-level chromophoric dissolved organic matter data for all lakes in three Upper Midwest ecoregions; (2) investigate long-term trends in lake chromophoric dissolved organic matter in the northern US using historical Landsat imagery; (3) determine relationships between landscape properties, climate and chromophoric dissolved organic matter levels and characteristics; and (4) elucidate relationships between dissolved organic matter characteristics and effects on water treatment. The proposed research will provide educational benefits for up to six individuals: a postdoctoral researcher, graduate research assistant, and 2-4 undergraduate students. The PIs will organize workshops for managers of regional water management agencies and make presentations at state conferences and meetings of citizen-based lake associations. Project results will be used to update a heavily used public database of lake water clarity (http://water.umn.edu) to include the chromophoric dissolved organic matter census and time-trend data and their relevance to citizens. Additional enhancements to the web site include a blog and an interactive interface for citizens to ask questions and share information. Finally, we will explore several possibilities to permit citizens to gather chromophoric dissolved organic matter data, including a low-tech color wheel comparator and cellphone app. Citizen engagement will be a key component of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Colored dissolved organic matter, commonly written as the acronym CDOM, is a major component of the organic carbon pool in lakes. Over the past few decades, scientists have increasingly recognized the importance of CDOM in modifying or controlling conditions and processes in aquatic ecosystems. It also has important effects on human uses of lakes. In spite of the importance of CDOM, data on its occurrence and spatial and temporal variability in lakes are quite limited. In this project we used satellite imagery to obtain census-level information on CDOM levels in lakes of three large ecoregions in the Upper Great Lakes states of Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan.

 We first evaluated methods to correct Landsat 8 and Sentinel-2 imagery for varying atmospheric conditions to convert satellite sensor data to surface reflectance values, and we developed a robust protocol for retrieving CDOM data from atmospherically corrected imagery. We applied this atmospheric correction protocol to statewide imagery for Minnesota to produce census-level CDOM data for more than 10,000 lakes in the state for 2015 and 2016. Using 2016 imagery and Google Earth Engine, we also measured CDOM levels in more than 12,000 lakes in the Northern Lakes and Forests, North Central Hardwood Forests and Northern Minnesota Wetlands ecoregions that spread across the northern and central parts of Minnesota, Wisconsin, Michigan. We characterized spatial patterns of CDOM levels in the lakes in terms by ecoregion and state. We found that nearly all highly colored lakes occurred in the Northern Lakes and Forests ecoregion and high CDOM lakes were associated with forested, wetlands-rich catchments. In addition, we estimated dissolved organic carbon (DOC) pool sizes across lakes in Minnesota using remotely sensed estimates of DOC concentration and lake volume estimated from a model using catchment area digital elevation maps

 The extensive ground-based measurements we collected to calibrate satellite imagery for retrieval of CDOM data enabled us to make three important conclusions. First, we found that CDOM is a very good predictor of DOC concentration in visibly colored lakes but not so good in lakes with low CDOM levels. Second, we found that dissolved iron has only minor effects on the parameter (light absorption coefficient at 440 nm, a440) usually used to quantify CDOM, indicating that this parameter effectively is a measures the colored fraction of dissolved organic matter (CDOM). Moreover, we found that dissolved iron does not influence estimates of DOC from a440. Third, in collaboration with scientists from Minnesota's Pollution Control Agency, we found that CDOM affects measurement of Secchi depth above the a440 level of 4 m-1, which is in the low-moderate range, and concluded that Secchi depth by itself is an inadequate metric for eutrophication impairment in colored Minnesota lakes. This information is being used by the MPCA to refine state water quality standards.

We assembled historical data on color and CDOM for Minnesota and nearby areas, including a 70-year daily color record for the Mississippi River at Minneapolis, and found no simple long-term temporal trends in CDOM. Shorter-term trends were observed at seasonal and sub-decadal scales primarily in relation to river flow and precipitation patterns.

Based on laboratory studies, we found that chlorine demand, an important cost component in drinking water treatment, increased linearly with CDOM levels in potential source waters for public water supplies. Formation of potentially toxic trihalomethane disinfection byproducts (DBPs) also increased linearly with CDOM level in source waters, but formation of di- and tri-haloacetic acids (also of human health concern) increased in logarithmic fashion with increasing CDOM.

We developed two procedures to measure CDOM levels in surface waters using smartphone cameras. The procedures, which basically are analogous to the retrieval of CDOM data from satellite imagery, use the red/green/blue (RGB) data of smartphone photo images of either (1) a Secchi disk suspended at a fixed depth in water or (2) a white plastic bucket of fixed dimensions filled with lake water. These results provide an opportunity to develop a smartphone app to facilitate the process and enable citizen scientists to participate in CDOM monitoring.

Short videos were developed to describe (1) how CDOM affects lake ecosystem processes and human uses of colored lakes and (2) how CDOM is measured. The videos are available on YouTube and can be accessed via our web site (https://water.rs.umn.edu/CDOM). This site was extensively revised to include major findings of our CDOM research. The web-based lake browser (https://lakes.rs.umn.edu), which enables searches for water quality data on Minnesota lakes, also was revised to include our satellite-based data on CDOM.
